title: Induction and Stabilization of Gamma Oscillations With 40 Hz Transcranial Alternating Current Stimulation in Healthy Elderly
description_brief: This study aims to compare the efficacy of different 40 Hz tACS protocols in entraining gamma oscillations, which are linked to various cognitive functions and play a significant role in cognitive impairments like Alzheimer's disease. Specifically, it examines the effects of 40 Hz tACS applied to frontal brain regions versus fronto-temporal regions on gamma oscillations and working memory in healthy elderly individuals.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is 40 Hz transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) aimed at entraining gamma oscillations and measuring effects on working memory in healthy elderly — an intervention intended to improve cognitive function rather than deliver a biologic or small-molecule that targets Alzheimer pathology. The trial description and registry entry identify the protocol as 40 Hz tACS applied to frontal vs fronto‑temporal regions in healthy older adults. citeturn0search6

Act: Key extracted details — Title: "Induction and Stabilization of Gamma Oscillations With 40 Hz Transcranial Alternating Current Stimulation in Healthy Elderly"; Intervention: 40 Hz tACS (noninvasive electrical brain stimulation); Population: healthy elderly; Outcomes: entrainment of gamma oscillations and working memory performance. This is a neuromodulation approach used to enhance cognitive/working memory function and is not a drug (no pharmaceutical agent named). Prior literature shows 40 Hz tACS/GENUS is used to induce gamma entrainment and has been studied for cognitive effects and as a possible therapeutic approach for Alzheimer’s-related cognitive impairment. citeturn0search6turn0search1turn0search9

Reflect: Classification check — the trial does not test a biologic (e.g., antibody) nor a small-molecule drug, and it is not focused on treating neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms; its primary aim is cognitive (working memory) modulation via gamma entrainment. Therefore it best fits the 'cognitive enhancer' category. Note: some 40 Hz entrainment research also explores disease-modifying mechanisms (e.g., effects on microglia/amyloid in preclinical or multimodal stimulation studies), but this specific study in healthy elderly targets cognitive entrainment/performance rather than direct pathology modulation, so 'cognitive enhancer' is the appropriate classification. citeturn0search9turn0search2

Web search results (selected sources used to verify and support the above): - Trial registry/summary for the 40 Hz tACS induction/stabilization study (NCT06740864) — trial description and aims. citeturn0search6 - Phase‑synchronized 40 Hz tACS and iTBS study showing 40‑Hz tACS can enhance and stabilize gamma oscillatory activity (implications for cognitive function/AD). citeturn0search1 - Meta-analysis and clinical studies examining 40 Hz gamma‑tACS effects on cognition in AD and related populations. citeturn0search0turn0search2 - GENUS / 40 Hz sensory stimulation literature showing gamma entrainment can affect brain function and has been explored for cognitive and disease‑relevant outcomes. citeturn0search9
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is 40 Hz transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) to entrain/stabilize gamma oscillations and thereby improve cognitive/working-memory performance in healthy older adults. This is a neuromodulation-based cognitive-enhancement approach aimed at restoring network-level oscillatory activity and synaptic function rather than targeting an amyloid, tau, inflammatory, metabolic, or molecular pathway with a drug. citeturn1search5turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — Title: "Induction and Stabilization of Gamma Oscillations With 40 Hz Transcranial Alternating Current Stimulation in Healthy Elderly"; Intervention: 40 Hz tACS (noninvasive electrical brain stimulation); Population: healthy elderly; Primary aim: entrain gamma oscillations and measure working-memory/cognitive effects. No pharmaceutical agent or molecular target is named, so the study is best classified as a cognitive-enhancer / synaptic-plasticity intervention. citeturn1search5turn0search6
